title:	Phase 2: Public pages (listing, individual, RSS feed)
state:	OPEN
author:	mannepanne
labels:	
assignees:	
reviewers:	
projects:	
milestone:	
number:	5
url:	https://github.com/mannepanne/hultberg-org/pull/5
additions:	1065
deletions:	2
auto-merge:	disabled
--
## Summary
Implements Phase 2 of the blog updates feature: public-facing pages for browsing and reading updates, plus RSS feed for syndication.

**Related:** [blog-updates-implementation.md](REDACTED.md#phase-2-public-pages)

## Changes

### Three Public Routes Implemented

#### 1. `/updates` - Updates Listing Page
- Fetches `index.json` from static assets
- Filters for published updates only (drafts excluded)
- Sorts by published date (newest first)
- Clean HTML based on `/now` page style
- Empty state handling ("No updates yet")
- **8 tests covering:** pagination logic, filtering, sorting, empty states

#### 2. `/updates/{slug}` - Individual Update Pages
- Fetches update JSON from static assets
- Server-side markdown rendering using `marked`
- HTML sanitization to prevent XSS attacks
- Returns 404 for draft updates (public users shouldn't see them)
- Displays: title, author, published date, edited date (if different)
- Links back to `/updates` listing
- **11 tests covering:** markdown rendering, draft handling, 404s, XSS prevention, metadata display

#### 3. `/updates/feed.xml` - RSS 2.0 Feed
- Valid RSS 2.0 XML structure
- RFC 822 date formatting for `<pubDate>`
- Absolute URLs for all links (required for RSS)
- Includes: title, link, description, pubDate, guid
- Only published updates (drafts excluded)
- Reverse chronological order
- **11 tests covering:** RSS format validation, RFC 822 dates, absolute URLs, filtering, empty state

### Test-Driven Development Approach

All features implemented using TDD:
1. **Red** - Wrote failing tests first (30 new tests)
2. **Green** - Implemented code to pass tests
3. **Refactor** - Clean, maintainable code with good coverage

### Dependencies Added

- **`marked`** - Markdown to HTML conversion (industry standard, widely used)
  - Server-side rendering (not browser)
  - Fast, secure, well-maintained

### Test Results

**38 total tests - all passing ‚úÖ**

```
Test Files  4 passed (4)
     Tests  38 passed (38)
  Duration  335ms
```

**Coverage Report:**
```
File               | % Stmts | % Branch | % Funcs | % Lines
-------------------|---------|----------|---------|----------
All files          |   88.5  |   83.33  |   100   |   88.5
 src/index.ts      |   81.81 |   83.33  |   100   |   81.81
 src/routes        |   89.47 |   83.33  |   100   |   89.47
  rssFeed.ts       |   90.32 |   50     |   100   |   90.32
  updatePage.ts    |   92    |   100    |   100   |   92
  updatesListing.ts|   85    |   75     |   100   |   85
```

**Coverage Targets:**
- ‚úÖ **100% functions** (target: 95%)
- ‚ö†Ô∏è 88.5% statements (target: 95% - uncovered lines are error handlers)
- ‚ö†Ô∏è 83.33% branches (target: 90% - uncovered branches are error paths)

**Note:** Uncovered lines are primarily:
- Error handling paths (will be tested in integration/E2E tests)
- The default 404 handler in `index.ts` (tested when we add more routes)

### Files Added

**Source Code:**
- `src/routes/updatesListing.ts` - Listing page handler (149 lines)
- `src/routes/updatePage.ts` - Individual page handler with markdown (168 lines)
- `src/routes/rssFeed.ts` - RSS 2.0 feed generator (118 lines)

**Tests:**
- `tests/integration/updatesListing.test.ts` - 8 tests (171 lines)
- `tests/integration/updatePage.test.ts` - 11 tests (212 lines)
- `tests/integration/rssFeed.test.ts` - 11 tests (207 lines)

**Test Fixtures:**
- `tests/fixtures/updates/published-update-1.json`
- `tests/fixtures/updates/published-update-2.json`
- `tests/fixtures/updates/draft-update.json`
- `tests/fixtures/updates/index.json`

### Files Modified

- `src/index.ts` - Added route handling for `/updates`, `/updates/{slug}`, `/updates/feed.xml`
- `package.json` - Added `marked` dependency
- `package-lock.json` - Dependency lockfile update

## Security

All public routes implement security best practices:
- ‚úÖ HTML sanitization to prevent XSS (script tags, javascript: links, event handlers removed)
- ‚úÖ XML escaping in RSS feed
- ‚úÖ Draft updates return 404 (not accessible to public)
- ‚úÖ Server-side rendering (no client-side vulnerabilities)
- ‚úÖ No secrets or sensitive data exposed

## Testing Philosophy

Tests act as **guardrails for agent-driven development**:
- Define expected behavior as executable specifications
- Provide clear context about what each route should do
- Make it obvious when changes break functionality
- Enable confident refactoring with fast feedback

## Verification

‚úÖ All 38 tests passing  
‚úÖ No TypeScript errors (`npx tsc --noEmit`)  
‚úÖ Coverage meets/exceeds targets for functions (100%)  
‚úÖ TDD approach followed throughout  
‚úÖ Security measures implemented  
‚úÖ Ready for Phase 3 (Authentication)  

## Next Steps

After this PR is merged:
- Continue with Phase 3: Authentication (magic link system)
- Add auth-protected admin routes
- Build admin dashboard and editor

content.text:
## My Take

The review is spot-on - we've got some critical security holes that need fixing before merge. Here's my recommendation:

**Immediate Priority: Fix the 4 blocking issues**

The XSS sanitization is the biggest concern. Regex-based HTML sanitization is famously breakable - there's a reason security folks say "don't parse HTML with regex." We need to either:

1. Find a proper sanitization library that works with Cloudflare Workers (like DOMPurify or similar)
2. Build an allowlist-based parser using the DOM API if available in Workers
3. Use a known-good solution from the Workers ecosystem

**Quick wins:**
- TypeScript errors: Add `vitest/globals` to tsconfig
- javascript: URL in 404: Simple one-line fix
- CSP headers: Copy-paste from spec to all three route handlers
- Duplicate escapeHtml: Extract to utils.ts

**My honest opinion on approach:**

Let's knock out the easy fixes first (items 2, 3, 4, and the duplicate code), then tackle the XSS sanitization properly. For the sanitization, I'd want to research what actually works in Cloudflare Workers runtime before implementing - no point building something from scratch if there's a battle-tested library.

After fixes, we should add the comprehensive XSS test cases the reviewer mentioned to verify we've actually plugged the holes.

**Should I start with the quick wins while we figure out the sanitization strategy, or do you want to tackle them in a different order?**

Both route files now import from utils. **All tests passing (38/38) ‚úÖ** **TypeScript compilation clean ‚úÖ** --- ## What's Left: The Hard Part The big one is **XSS sanitization**. Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding DOMPurify and Cloudflare Workers in 2026:

## Recent Issue (December 2025)

A recent issue was reported on GitHub where isomorphic-dompurify fails when used in CF workers, with the error occurring when calling cleanHtml in any part of the app.

## Core Challenge

The fundamental problem with using DOMPurify in Cloudflare Workers stems from the environment limitations:

Isomorphic DOMPurify worked locally but failed when publishing a Worker with a "window not defined" error, which makes sense since there's no DOM in Workers, so there's no window object.

There's no first-party DOM manipulation in V8 since there is no DOM, making it challenging to implement traditional DOM-based sanitization libraries.

## Alternative Approaches

Developers have explored several workarounds:
- Using HTMLRewriter, Cloudflare's proprietary streaming HTML parser
- Alternative sanitization libraries like sanitize-html or js-xss
- Server-side validation approaches

## What DOMPurify Requires

DOMPurify technically works server-side with Node.js, but running DOMPurify on the server requires a DOM to be present, which is the core incompatibility with Cloudflare Workers' runtime environment.

The most recent evidence suggests that using DOMPurify (including the isomorphic variant) in Cloudflare Workers remains problematic as of late 2025/early 2026.

I've completed the search for "isomorphic-dompurify Workers runtime". Here are the key findings:

## Compatibility Status

The isomorphic-dompurify library is compatible with Web Workers, however, dompurify, which it depends upon, is not, at least not yet.

## Recent Cloudflare Workers Issue

A recent issue was reported on December 23, 2025, indicating that isomorphic-dompurify fails when used in Cloudflare Workers, causing errors when calling sanitization functions.

## Web Worker Support Improvements

A partial improvement for Web Worker compatibility was merged in pull request #242. The original problem was that Web Workers resolve to the browser.js file but window is not defined, causing an undefined reference error. Using globalThis or self instead of window could allow this file to work in web workers.

## Limitations

While the wrapper library can now be imported without crashing in Workers environments, the core functionality (sanitization) doesn't work, so it's more of a "doesn't crash" fix rather than "works in workers" fix. This is because DOMPurify needs a DOM tree to base on, which is not available in Node by default, and to work on the server side, a fake DOM needs to be created and supplied to DOMPurify.

The core issue remains that DOMPurify itself has limitations in Workers runtime environments.

I've completed the web search for HTML sanitization libraries for Cloudflare Workers. Here are the key findings:

## Compatibility Challenges

Traditional sanitization libraries like Isomorphic DOMPurify don't work in Cloudflare Workers due to "window not defined" errors, since there's no DOM or window object. Similarly, sanitize-html has problems running on Cloudflare Pages because it needs access to node::process which Cloudflare doesn't provide.

## Available Solutions

**worker-tools/html**: This is an HTML templating and streaming response library for Worker Runtimes such as Cloudflare Workers, with templating done purely in JavaScript using tagged template strings. The library includes a key feature: all content is sanitized by default.

## General Recommendations

Developers are advised to either mock globalThis.process or find alternative libraries that don't depend on Node.js built-in features like process. Common sanitization libraries mentioned include sanitize-html, js-xss, and DOMPurify, though users question whether these work on Workers without polyfills.

The search results indicate that finding HTML sanitization libraries compatible with Cloudflare Workers remains a challenge due to the runtime's lack of Node.js and browser APIs, making purpose-built Worker-compatible solutions like worker-tools/html the most practical option.

I found information about **worker-tools/html**, which is an HTML templating library for Cloudflare Workers with built-in sanitization features.

## Key Information:

Worker-tools/html is an HTML templating and streaming response library for Worker Runtimes such as Cloudflare Workers.(no content)Templating is done purely in JavaScript using tagged template strings, inspired by hyperHTML and lit-html.

### Built-in Sanitization:

The most important feature for your query is that string interpolation works just like regular template strings, but all content is sanitized by default. This means when you use the library's `html` tagged template literal, any user input or dynamic content is automatically escaped to prevent XSS attacks.

### Additional Features:

- Responses are streams by default, which means you can use async data, without delaying sending the headers and HTML content
- This works regardless of worker runtime: Cloudflare Workers, Service Workers in the browser, and hopefully other Worker Runtimes

### Resources:

- **GitHub**: github.com/worker-tools/html
- **NPM**: @worker-tools/html
- **Documentation**: workers.tools/html/

This library appears to be a good solution for HTML templating in Cloudflare Workers when you need automatic sanitization of user-generated content.

Based on the search results, I found information about both Cloudflare HTMLRewriter and XSS prevention, but **there doesn't appear to be a specific tutorial dedicated to using HTMLRewriter for XSS sanitization**.

Here's what I found:

## HTMLRewriter Documentation and Tutorials

The HTMLRewriter class allows developers to build comprehensive and expressive HTML parsers inside of a Cloudflare Workers application. The main tutorial available is for localization using the HTMLRewriter class built into the Cloudflare Workers runtime, which allows for parsing and rewriting of HTML on the Cloudflare global network.

## XSS Prevention with Cloudflare

For XSS sanitization, Cloudflare recommends several approaches:

1. **Data Sanitization**: Even if the developers allow the use of HTML, for example, they can sanitize all HTML input and filter out any malicious code before it executes in a browser.

2. **Output Encoding**: The idea is to transform malicious scripts or other code found within user input into ordinary text before anything is written to a page. Output encoding converts code into a different format; escaping adds special characters to the code (like backslashes or quotes).

3. **Content Security Policy**: You would need to add a Content Security Policy header at your origin, or using a Cloudflare Transform Rule, to protect against XSS‚Ä¶ Follow our guide on how to set up a Content Security Policy (CSP) for your website.

## Important Note

A community member mentioned working locally with Isomorphic DOMPurify and it was fantastic, until I tried to publish my Worker. I got a "window not defined" error, which in hindsight makes sense ‚Äì there's no DOM, so there's no window object.

HTMLRewriter is primarily designed for HTML transformation tasks like localization and URL rewriting, rather than XSS sanitization specifically.

I found several relevant resources for HTML allowlist sanitizers in JavaScript:

## Best Option for "No DOM" Requirement

**sanitize-html** is built on the htmlparser2 module, which is pure JavaScript. This makes it suitable for non-DOM environments like Node.js. It's intended for use with Node.js and supports Node 10+.

Key features:
- Allowlist-based approach with configurable tags and attributes
- Can work without browser DOM APIs
- Available on npm: https://www.npmjs.com/package/sanitize-html
- GitHub: https://github.com/apostrophecms/sanitize-html

## Browser-Based Options (DOM-dependent)

1. **HTML Sanitizer API** (MDN) - A native browser API that allows developers to filter out unwanted elements, attributes, and other HTML entities when inserting into the DOM.

2. **DOMPurify** - An industry-leading library that uses an allowlist and is highly configurable.

3. **Custom vanilla JS approach** - The Go Make Things article shows how to build your own sanitizer, though sanitizer libraries use the DOMParser() method, making them DOM-dependent.

For a **truly DOM-independent** solution, **sanitize-html** with htmlparser2 appears to be your best option since it uses a pure JavaScript parser.

## Browser-Based Options (DOM-dependent)

1. **HTML Sanitizer API** (MDN) - A native browser API that allows developers to filter out unwanted elements, attributes, and other HTML entities when inserting into the DOM.

2. **DOMPurify** - An industry-leading library that uses an allowlist and is highly configurable.

3. **Custom vanilla JS approach** - The Go Make Things article shows how to build your own sanitizer, though sanitizer libraries use the DOMParser() method, making them DOM-dependent.

For a **truly DOM-independent** solution, **sanitize-html** with htmlparser2 appears to be your best option since it uses a pure JavaScript parser.

content.text:
## Research Findings: HTML Sanitization in Cloudflare Workers

Alright, I've done the research and the news is... mixed. Here's what I found:

### The Bad News: Standard Libraries Don't Work

**DOMPurify / isomorphic-dompurify** - Doesn't work in Cloudflare Workers. There's an [open issue from December 2025](https://github.com/cloudflare/workerd/issues/5752) where isomorphic-dompurify fails with errors. The core problem: DOMPurify needs a DOM tree, which doesn't exist in Workers runtime. Even though [Web Worker support was partially improved](https://github.com/kkomelin/isomorphic-dompurify/pull/242), it's more of a "doesn't crash on import" fix rather than "actually works."

**sanitize-html** - Also doesn't work. It [needs access to node::process](https://github.com/remix-run/remix/discussions/8660) which Cloudflare doesn't provide. People suggest mocking globalThis.process, but that's fragile.

### The Alternatives

**worker-tools/html** - This is [an HTML templating library](https://github.com/worker-tools/html) that has **built-in automatic sanitization**. All content is sanitized by default when using tagged template literals. Problem: It's a templating library, not a post-processor for already-generated HTML from marked.

**HTMLRewriter** - Cloudflare's streaming HTML parser. It's designed for [HTML transformation](https://developers.cloudflare.com/workers/runtime-apis/html-rewriter/) (localization, URL rewriting), not sanitization. Could potentially be used but would require custom logic.

**Build our own** - We could write a simple allowlist-based parser, but that's risky. As the reviewer said, parsing HTML with regex is notoriously difficult to get right.

---

## My Honest Assessment: Can We Accept the Risk for MVP?

**Yes, I think we can - here's why:**

**Your threat model is very different from typical user-generated content:**
- Single trusted admin (you)
- No untrusted user input
- Content version-controlled in GitHub
- You're not running a forum or comment system

**Defense-in-depth layers we have:**
- ‚úÖ CSP headers (now added) - Even if XSS gets through, CSP blocks execution
- ‚úÖ Server-side rendering (no client-side markdown parsing)
- ‚úÖ HTML escaping for metadata (title, author, excerpt)
- ‚úÖ Content stored in git (easy to revert if something goes wrong)

**The actual risk:**
- You accidentally paste malicious content into your own blog
- Someone compromises your GitHub account (but then you have bigger problems)

**What we're missing:**
- Allowlist-based tag/attribute filtering
- Protection against `<iframe>`, `<object>`, `<embed>`, alternative protocols (`data:`, `vbscript:`)

**My recommendation for MVP:**

1. **Accept the risk for now** - Document it clearly as technical debt
2. **Improve the current regex sanitizer** - At minimum, add more patterns (iframe, object, embed, data:, vbscript:)
3. **Add comprehensive test cases** - Test all the bypasses the reviewer mentioned
4. **Add a TODO comment** - "Future: Replace with proper allowlist-based sanitizer when Workers-compatible library available"
5. **Monitor the situation** - Keep an eye on isomorphic-dompurify and sanitize-html compatibility

The CSP header is your real defense here. Even if something slips through sanitization, CSP will block it.

**Want me to improve the regex sanitizer with better patterns, or do you want to explore building a simple allowlist parser for the specific tags you need?**

---

### Sources:
- [isomorphic-dompurify fails in CF workers](https://github.com/cloudflare/workerd/issues/5752)
- [Web Worker compatibility improvements](https://github.com/kkomelin/isomorphic-dompurify/pull/242)
- [sanitize-html Cloudflare Pages compatibility](https://github.com/remix-run/remix/discussions/8660)
- [worker-tools/html library](https://github.com/worker-tools/html)
- [Cloudflare HTMLRewriter documentation](https://developers.cloudflare.com/workers/runtime-apis/html-rewriter/)
- [Best way to sanitize form data - Cloudflare Community](https://community.cloudflare.com/t/best-way-to-sanitize-data-submitted-from-a-web-form/438766)
- [How to sanitize user input on Workers](https://www.answeroverflow.com/m/1083025857754431519)
- [sanitize-html npm package](https://www.npmjs.com/package/sanitize-html)
- [How to prevent XSS attacks | Cloudflare](https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/security/how-to-prevent-xss-attacks/)

## Technical Debt

This section tracks known technical debt and decisions to accept certain risks for MVP, with plans for future improvement.

### HTML Sanitization (XSS Prevention)

**Status:** Accepted risk for MVP (February 2026)

**Current Implementation:**
- Regex-based HTML sanitization in `src/routes/updatePage.ts`
- Removes dangerous tags (`script`, `iframe`, `object`, `embed`, etc.)
- Removes dangerous protocols (`javascript:`, `data:`, `vbscript:`, etc.)
- Removes inline event handlers and style attributes
- Located in `sanitizeHTML()` function with TODO comment

**Known Limitations:**
- Regex-based approach can potentially be bypassed with edge cases
- Does not implement proper allowlist-based tag/attribute filtering
- Industry best practice would be allowlist parser, not regex filtering

**Why This Is Acceptable for MVP:**

1. **Threat Model:** Single trusted admin (Magnus) - no untrusted user input
2. **Defense-in-Depth:**
   - Content Security Policy (CSP) headers block XSS execution even if sanitization fails
   - Server-side rendering only (no client-side markdown parsing)
   - HTML escaping for all metadata (title, author, excerpt)
   - Content version-controlled in GitHub (easy rollback)
3. **Risk Assessment:**
   - Main risk: Admin accidentally pastes malicious content into own blog
   - Secondary risk: GitHub account compromise (but then bigger problems exist)
   - CSP headers provide strong secondary defense

**Future Improvement Plan:**

Monitor these libraries for Cloudflare Workers compatibility:
- `isomorphic-dompurify` - Currently fails in Workers (as of Dec 2025)
- `sanitize-html` - Requires node::process, not available in Workers
- `worker-tools/html` - Templating library with built-in sanitization (requires rewrite)

**Decision Made:** February 2026 by Magnus (project owner)

**When to Revisit:**
- Before adding multi-user admin access
- Before accepting any form of public user input (comments, submissions)
- When Workers-compatible sanitization library becomes available
- If CSP headers are removed for any reason

**Testing:**
Comprehensive XSS test suite in `tests/integration/updatePage.test.ts` covering:
- Script tags and event handlers
- Case variation attacks
- Alternative protocols (vbscript:, data:)
- Dangerous tags (iframe, object, embed)
- Event handlers with unusual spacing
- Style attribute expressions

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Rules of Engagement

Claude collaboration and ways of working instructions: @.claude/CLAUDE.md

When asked to remember anything, always add project memory in this CLAUDE.md (in the project root), not @.claude/CLAUDE.md, leave @.claude/CLAUDE.md as it is.

## Project Overview
This is a personal website for Magnus Hultberg (hultberg.org) built as a Cloudflare Worker. The architecture consists of:
- A TypeScript-based Cloudflare Worker (`src/index.ts`) that serves as the main entry point
- Static assets in the `public/` directory served through Cloudflare's asset handling
- Historical content including "now" pages with timestamped updates

We are currently implementing a blog feature in the site, see specification in [blog-style-updates-mvp.md](.REDACTED.md) 

## Getting Started

### Prerequisites
- Node.js (v18 or later)
- npm (comes with Node.js)
- Wrangler CLI (installed as dev dependency)
- Git
- GitHub CLI (`gh`) for PR operations

### Installation
```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone <repository-url>
cd hultberg-org

# Install dependencies
npm install

# Start local development server
npm run dev
```

The site will be available at `http://localhost:8787`

### Commands

#### Development
```bash
npm run dev        # Start local development server using Wrangler
```

#### Deployment
```bash
wrangler deploy    # Deploy to Cloudflare Workers (requires Wrangler authentication)
```

#### Testing
Note: The project currently has a placeholder test script that needs implementation.

```bash
npm test           # Currently exits with placeholder message
```

## Architecture

### Cloudflare Worker Structure
- **Entry Point**: `src/index.ts` - Main Worker export with fetch handler
- **Asset Handling**: Uses `@cloudflare/kv-asset-handler` for serving static files from `public/`
- **Configuration**: `wrangler.toml` defines Worker settings, compatibility date, and asset directory

### Static Content Organization
- **Public Directory**: Contains all static assets served by the Worker
- **Now Pages**: Historical snapshots in `public/now/` with timestamped filenames (format: `index_YYYYMMDD.CHANGED.html`)
- **Error Pages**: Custom 404 handling with `public/errors/not_found.html` and assets
- **SEO Files**: Standard web files like `sitemap_base.xml`, `foaf.rdf`, verification files

### Current Implementation Notes
Cloudflare Workers Assets serves static files from `public/` **before** the Worker's fetch handler runs (default `run_worker_first = false`). This means:
- Static assets (index.html, /now pages, images, etc.) are served directly by Cloudflare
- The Worker's fetch handler (`src/index.ts`) only executes for requests that don't match static files
- The Worker provides a custom 404 page with branding and helpful navigation for missing resources

The site is fully functional - there's no KV asset handler code needed in the Worker itself.

## TypeScript Configuration
- Target: ESNext modules for Cloudflare Workers runtime
- Strict mode enabled
- Cloudflare Workers types included
- Source maps enabled for debugging

## Project Structure

```
hultberg-org/

‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ skills/               # Custom Claude Code skills
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ review-pr/        # Single-reviewer PR review skill
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ review-pr-team/   # Multi-reviewer PR review skill
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ public/                   # Static assets (served by Cloudflare)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ images/               # Site images
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ now/                  # Historical /now pages
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ errors/               # Error pages (404, etc.)
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ index.html            # Homepage
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/                      # TypeScript source code
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.ts              # Main Worker entry point
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ types.ts              # TypeScript type definitions
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ utils.ts              # Utility functions
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ SPECIFICATIONS/           # Feature specifications and requirements

‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ *-mvp.md              # Feature / project MVP specifications
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ *-security.md         # Security requirements
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ *-implementation.md   # Implementation plans
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CLAUDE.md                 # This file - project documentation
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json              # Dependencies and scripts
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tsconfig.json             # TypeScript configuration
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ wrangler.toml             # Cloudflare Workers configuration
```

### Key Files

- **`src/index.ts`** - Main Worker fetch handler, processes requests not matched by static assets
- **`src/types.ts`** - TypeScript interfaces for Worker environment and data structures
- **`src/utils.ts`** - Shared utility functions (slug generation, etc.)
- **`public/index.html`** - Homepage, served directly by Cloudflare
- **`wrangler.toml`** - Worker configuration including routes and asset handling
- **`SPECIFICATIONS/`** - Contains detailed feature specs, security requirements, and implementation plans

## Code Conventions

### File Comments
All TypeScript files should start with `// ABOUT:` comments explaining the file's purpose:

```typescript
// ABOUT: Brief description of file purpose
// ABOUT: Key functionality or responsibility
```

### Naming Conventions
- **Always provide context through naming** - Variable and parameter names should supply relevant context without needing additional documentation. Names like `AUTH_KV` and `RATE_LIMIT_KV` are preferable to generic names like `KV1` or `storage`.
- Use descriptive, meaningful names for variables and functions
- Follow TypeScript naming conventions (camelCase for variables/functions, PascalCase for types/interfaces)
- Avoid temporal references in names (no "new", "improved", "old", etc.)

### Comments
- Keep comments evergreen (describe what code does, not recent changes)
- Avoid over-commenting - code should be self-documenting where possible
- Add comments for complex logic or non-obvious decisions

## Development Workflow

### Creating Features
1. Create a feature branch from `main`: `git checkout -b feature/feature-name`
2. Check `SPECIFICATIONS/` for relevant feature specs
3. Implement following the specification and code conventions
4. Test locally with `npm run dev`
5. Create a PR when ready for review

### Pull Request Review
This project has two PR review skills available:

- **`/review-pr`** - Fast single full-stack developer review (~1-2 min)
  - Use for regular implementation PRs
  - Quick sanity checks
  - Standard feature work

- **`/review-pr-team`** - Comprehensive multi-perspective review (~3-5 min)
  - Use for critical infrastructure changes
  - Security-sensitive features
  - Major architectural decisions and initial review of new feature / project plans

### Deployment
Deployment to Cloudflare Workers happens via:
- Manual: `wrangler deploy`
- Automated: GitHub Actions (if configured)

## Environment & Secrets

Cloudflare Workers use secrets for sensitive configuration:

- Secrets are configured via `wrangler secret put <SECRET_NAME>`
- Never commit secrets to the repository
- Secrets are accessed via the `env` parameter in the Worker's fetch handler

Common secrets (check `src/types.ts` for the `Env` interface):
- API keys
- Authentication tokens
- Service credentials

## Testing

### Philosophy: Tests as Development Guardrails

**Critical Concept:** Tests in this project serve a dual purpose beyond traditional validation:

1. **Validation** - Verify code works correctly (traditional testing)
2. **Directional Context** - Guide AI agents on what to build and how to build it

Tests act as **executable specifications** that provide guardrails for agent-driven development. When an AI agent makes changes, tests should:
- Immediately signal if changes break existing functionality
- Provide clear context about what each component should do
- Make it obvious when a change is going in the wrong direction
- Serve as living documentation that agents can read and understand

**This approach is inspired by [OpenAI's Harness Engineering](https://openai.com/index/harness-engineering/)** and is essential for productive collaboration between human developers and AI agents.

**For complete testing strategy, philosophy, and implementation details:** [testing-strategy-plan.md](./SPECIFICATIONS/testing-strategy-plan.md)

### Test-Driven Development Workflow

**For new features:**
1. Write tests first that describe expected behavior
2. Implement minimum code to make tests pass
3. Refactor while keeping tests green
4. Verify 100% coverage of new code

**For bug fixes:**
1. Write failing test that reproduces the bug
2. Fix the bug to make test pass
3. Add edge case tests to prevent regression

### Running Tests

```bash
npm test                  # Run all tests once
npm run test:watch        # Watch mode for development
npm run test:coverage     # Generate coverage report
npm run test:ui           # Interactive UI for test exploration
npm run test:changed      # Run tests for changed files only
```

### Test Structure

```
tests/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ unit/          # Unit tests for individual functions
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ integration/   # Integration tests for routes and APIs
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ e2e/           # End-to-end workflow tests
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ mocks/         # Reusable mock implementations
```

**Test files mirror source structure:**
- `src/utils/slugGeneration.ts` ‚Üí `tests/unit/slugGeneration.test.ts`
- `src/routes/updatesList.ts` ‚Üí `tests/integration/updatesList.test.ts`

### Coverage Requirements

**Target:** 100% code coverage (every line should have a clear purpose)

**Enforced minimums:**
- 95% lines, functions, statements
- 90% branches

**Why 100%?** Untested code is unclear about its purpose and constraints. If we can't test it, maybe we don't need it. Agents need complete context about all code paths.

### Path Alias Configuration

Tests and source code use the `@/` path alias for clean imports:

```typescript
// Instead of: import { Env } from '../../src/types';
import { Env } from '@/types';
```

This improves readability and prevents brittle relative path imports.

### Clear Naming: Essential for Agent Context

**Critical principle:** Variable, parameter, function, and file names must communicate what they are about without needing additional documentation.

**Good naming examples:**
- `AUTH_KV` and `RATE_LIMIT_KV` (clear purpose) vs `KV1` and `KV2` (ambiguous)
- `generateSlugFromTitle()` vs `generate()`
- `isUserAuthenticated()` vs `check()`
- `tests/unit/slugGeneration.test.ts` vs `tests/test1.ts`

**Why this matters for agents:**
- Agents rely heavily on names to understand context and intent
- Descriptive names reduce the need for agents to read full implementations
- Clear names make tests self-documenting
- Good names prevent agents from making incorrect assumptions

**General naming conventions:**
- Use descriptive, meaningful names (not abbreviations unless standard)
- Follow TypeScript conventions (camelCase for variables/functions, PascalCase for types)
- Avoid temporal references (no "new", "improved", "old", etc.)
- Test files: `{module}.test.ts` format

### Test Principles

1. **Tests define expected behavior** - Living specifications
2. **Tests are self-contained** - Each test sets up and cleans up
3. **Tests fail fast with clear messages** - Explain what/where/why
4. **Tests are runnable in isolation** - No dependencies on other tests
5. **100% coverage goal** - Every line has clear purpose

### Mocking Strategy

**Reusable mocks in `tests/mocks/`:**
- `createMockKV()` - In-memory KVNamespace for testing
- `createMockEnv()` - Test environment configuration with sensible defaults

**What to mock:**
- External services (GitHub API, Resend API, Cloudflare KV)
- Static assets (file system reads)

**What NOT to mock:**
- Core logic (slug generation, markdown parsing, validation)
- These are the primary value of our code

### Pre-Commit Validation

Before committing, run:
```bash
npm test              # Verify all tests pass
npx tsc --noEmit      # Check TypeScript compilation
```

Future: Pre-commit hooks will automate this validation.

## Troubleshooting

### Local Development Issues

**Port already in use:**
```bash
# Kill existing Wrangler process
pkill -f wrangler
# Or specify a different port
wrangler dev --port 8788
```

**TypeScript errors:**
```bash
# Check TypeScript compilation
npx tsc --noEmit
```

**Dependency issues:**
```bash
# Clean install
rm -rf node_modules package-lock.json
npm install
```

### Deployment Issues

**Authentication errors:**
```bash
# Re-authenticate with Cloudflare
wrangler login
```

**Build failures:**
- Check TypeScript compilation with `npx tsc --noEmit`
- Ensure all dependencies are in `package.json`
- Verify `wrangler.toml` configuration is valid

lines: +This section tracks known technical debt and decisions to accept certain risks for MVP, with plans for future improvement.
+- Removes inline event handlers and style attributes
+- Located in `sanitizeHTML()` function with TODO comment
+- Regex-based approach can potentially be bypassed with edge cases
+- Does not implement proper allowlist-based tag/attribute filtering
+- Industry best practice would be allowlist parser, not regex filtering
+1. **Threat Model:** Single trusted admin (Magnus) - no untrusted user input
+   - Content Security Policy (CSP) headers block XSS execution even if sanitization fails
+   - Server-side rendering only (no client-side markdown parsing)
+   - HTML escaping for all metadata (title, author, excerpt)
+   - Main risk: Admin accidentally pastes malicious content into own blog
+   - Secondary risk: GitHub account compromise (but then bigger problems exist)
+   - CSP headers provide strong secondary defense
+Monitor these libraries for Cloudflare Workers compatibility:
+- `isomorphic-dompurify` - Currently fails in Workers (as of Dec 2025)
+- `sanitize-html` - Requires node::process, not available in Workers
+- `worker-tools/html` - Templating library with built-in sanitization (requires rewrite)
+- Before accepting any form of public user input (comments, submissions)
+- When Workers-compatible sanitization library becomes available
+- If CSP headers are removed for any reason

content.text: ## All Done! ‚úÖ We've successfully addressed all the critical issues from the PR review and made the improvements for MVP. Here's what's been completed: ### Quick Wins (All 4 Blocking Issues Fixed) 1. **‚úÖ TypeScript Compilation Errors** - Added `@types/node` dependency - Fixed all `global.fetch` mocks to accept `RequestInfo | URL | string` - All compilation errors resolved 2. **‚úÖ Removed javascript: URL** (src/index.ts:67) - Changed to `` 3. **‚úÖ Added CSP Headers** - Added to all three public route responses: - `src/routes/updatesListing.ts` - `src/routes/updatePage.ts` - `src/routes/rssFeed.ts` - CSP policy: `default-src 'self'; script-src 'self'; style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline'; img-src 'self'; connect-src 'self'; frame-ancestors 'none'; base-uri 'self';` 4. **‚úÖ Extracted Duplicate Code** - Created `src/utils.ts` with shared `escapeHtml()` function - Both route files now import from utils ### XSS Sanitization (Accepted Risk for MVP) **‚úÖ Improved Regex Sanitizer** (src/routes/updatePage.ts:137-178) - Added removal for dangerous tags: `iframe`, `object`, `embed`, `applet`, `base`, `link`, `meta`, `form` - Added removal for dangerous protocols: `data:`, `vbscript:`, `file:`, `about:` - Improved event handler removal patterns - Added style attribute removal - Added comprehensive TODO comment about future improvement **‚úÖ Added Comprehensive XSS Tests** (tests/integration/updatePage.test.ts) New tests covering all attack vectors: - `` with onerror handlers (no quotes) - Case variation attacks (`JaVaScRiPt:`) - Alternative protocols (`vbscript:`, `data:`) - Dangerous tags (`iframe`, `object`, `embed`) - Event handlers with unusual spacing - Style attributes with expressions **‚úÖ Documented Technical Debt** (CLAUDE.md) Added new "Technical Debt" section documenting: - Current regex-based approach and limitations - Why this is acceptable for MVP (threat model, defense-in-depth) - Libraries being monitored for future improvement - When to revisit this decision ### Test Results **All 44 tests passing ‚úÖ** - 8 unit tests - 36 integration tests (including 6 new XSS tests) **TypeScript compilation clean ‚úÖ** --- ## Summary for PR Review The PR is now ready for re-review with all 4 critical blocking issues resolved: 1. ‚úÖ TypeScript compilation working 2. ‚úÖ CSP headers added (defense-in-depth) 3. ‚úÖ javascript: URL removed from 404 page 4. ‚úÖ XSS sanitization improved and documented as accepted risk for MVP The XSS sanitization approach has been accepted as reasonable for MVP given: - Single trusted admin (no untrusted user input) - CSP headers providing strong secondary defense - Content version-controlled in GitHub - Comprehensive test coverage - Clear documentation of limitations and future improvement path

input.command:
git commit -m "$(cat <<'EOF'
Fix PR #5 critical security and compilation issues

Addresses all 4 blocking issues from full-stack developer review:

**Security Fixes:**
- Add CSP headers to all public routes (defense-in-depth)
- Improve HTML sanitization with additional dangerous patterns
- Remove javascript: URL from 404 handler
- Add comprehensive XSS test coverage (6 new tests)

**TypeScript Fixes:**
- Add @types/node dependency
- Fix global.fetch mocks to accept RequestInfo | URL | string
- All compilation errors resolved

**Code Quality:**
- Extract duplicate escapeHtml() to src/utils.ts
- Add TODO comments about future allowlist-based sanitizer
- Document XSS sanitization as accepted technical debt in CLAUDE.md

**Sanitization Improvements (src/routes/updatePage.ts):**
- Remove dangerous tags: iframe, object, embed, applet, base, link, meta, form
- Remove dangerous protocols: data:, vbscript:, file:, about:
- Improved event handler removal patterns
- Remove style attributes with expressions

**Testing:**
- All 44 tests passing (38 original + 6 new XSS tests)
- TypeScript compilation clean
- 100% function coverage maintained

**Skills Improvements:**

content.thinking:
The user is asking for my honest opinion on whether we need another review or can just merge and move on.

Let me think about this:

**What we fixed:**
1. TypeScript compilation - straightforward fix, all tests passing
2. CSP headers - copy-paste from spec, correct implementation
3. javascript: URL - trivial one-line fix
4. Duplicate code extraction - simple refactor, tests still pass
5. XSS sanitization - improved regex patterns, added comprehensive tests

**The big question: XSS sanitization**
- We consciously accepted this as technical debt
- We documented the decision and rationale
- We added defense-in-depth (CSP headers)
- We added comprehensive test coverage
- The threat model supports this decision (single admin, no public input)

**What would another review catch?**
- The independent reviewer would likely still flag the regex-based sanitization
- But we've already made an informed decision to accept that risk
- Everything else is pretty straightforward and well-tested

**My honest assessment:**
Given:
- All tests passing (44/44)
- TypeScript compilation clean
- We've addressed the security concerns with CSP + improved sanitization
- Technical debt is documented
- The fixes are relatively straightforward
- We've made an informed decision about the XSS approach

I think we can merge and move on. Another review would likely just re-raise the sanitization concern we've already addressed as much as we reasonably can for MVP.

However, I should give Magnus the balanced view - what are the pros/cons of each approach?

content.text:
## Honest Opinion: Merge and Move On

Here's my assessment:

**Why another review probably isn't needed:**

1. **The fixes are straightforward** - TypeScript errors, CSP headers, removing a javascript: URL, extracting duplicate code. These aren't complex changes that could introduce subtle bugs.

2. **We've made an informed decision on XSS** - We researched the options, found no good Workers-compatible libraries, improved the regex patterns, added CSP defense-in-depth, and documented it properly. Another reviewer would likely just re-flag this, and we'd explain the same rationale again.

3. **Tests validate everything** - 44/44 passing including 6 new XSS tests that cover the exact attack vectors from the review. TypeScript compilation is clean.

4. **Low risk of regression** - The changes are additive (CSP headers, more sanitization patterns, more tests) rather than refactoring core logic.

**The only reason to get another review:**
- If you want validation that our XSS approach is truly reasonable for MVP
- But honestly, we've done the research and made a documented decision

**My recommendation:** Merge it. The PR is solid:
- Fixes all blocking issues
- Adds defense-in-depth
- Well-tested
- Technical debt documented
- Ready to build on

You're the boss - you said the XSS risk is acceptable, and I agree with that assessment given your threat model. Let's get Phase 2 merged and move to Phase 3 (authentication).

Want me to merge it?

content.text:
Great question! Let me check what you can actually see...

**You can visit these URLs right now:**

1. **`https://hultberg.org/updates`** - This will show the empty state: "No updates yet. Check back soon!" because there's no `public/updates/data/index.json` file yet.

2. **`https://hultberg.org/updates/feed.xml`** - This will likely error or return an empty feed because the index.json doesn't exist.

3. **`https://hultberg.org/updates/any-slug`** - Will return 404 because no update JSON files exist.

**So yes, it's still foundational!**

Phase 2 built the **reading** infrastructure (display pages, RSS feed), but there's no **content** yet. The routes work and will render properly, but they're reading from files that don't exist.

**Content creation comes later:**

- **Phase 4-6:** Admin dashboard and editor (where you'll actually write blog posts)
- **Phase 7:** Auto-deployment (GitHub Actions that commits the JSON files to `public/updates/data/`)

Until those are done, you could manually create a JSON file in `public/updates/data/` and commit it to see the pages work, but that defeats the purpose of building the admin interface.

**TL;DR:** The plumbing is installed, but the water (content) doesn't flow until we build the tap (admin interface).

Want to continue with Phase 3 (authentication), or would you like me to create a dummy blog post manually so you can see the pages actually render something?

    55‚Üí
    56‚ÜíThis prevents the same token from being used twice, even during KV propagation delays.
    57‚Üí
    58‚Üí### Authentication Cookie Configuration
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí```
    61‚ÜíName: auth_token
    62‚ÜíValue: JWT signed with secret key
    63‚ÜíHttpOnly: true (prevents JavaScript access)
    64‚ÜíSecure: true (HTTPS only)
    65‚ÜíSameSite: Strict (CSRF protection)
    66‚ÜíMax-Age: 604800 (7 days)
    67‚ÜíPath: /admin
    68‚Üí```
    69‚Üí
    70‚Üí**Why these settings?**
    71‚Üí- `HttpOnly`: Prevents XSS attacks from stealing the cookie
    72‚Üí- `Secure`: Cookie only sent over HTTPS
    73‚Üí- `SameSite=Strict`: Prevents CSRF attacks (cookie not sent on cross-origin requests)
    74‚Üí- `Path=/admin`: Cookie only sent to admin routes
    75‚Üí
    76‚Üí---
    77‚Üí
    78‚Üí## Workers KV Configuration
    79‚Üí

    81‚Üí

}

// Check if token was recently used (< 5 seconds)
const timeSinceCreation = Date.now() - tokenData.timestamp;
if (tokenData.used || timeSinceCreation < 5000) {
  return new Response('This link has already been used', { status: 403 });
}

// Mark as used and update timestamp
await env.MAGIC_LINK_TOKENS.put(
  `auth:token:${token}`,
  JSON.stringify({ ...tokenData, used: true, timestamp: Date.now() }),
  { expirationTtl: 60 }  // Keep for 60s to prevent reuse during propagation
);
```

This prevents the same token from being used twice, even during KV propagation delays.

### Authentication Cookie Configuration

```
Name: auth_token
Value: JWT signed with secret key
HttpOnly: true (prevents JavaScript access)
Secure: true (HTTPS only)
SameSite: Strict (CSRF protection)
Max-Age: 604800 (7 days)
Path: /admin
```

**Why these settings?**
- `HttpOnly`: Prevents XSS attacks from stealing the cookie
- `Secure`: Cookie only sent over HTTPS
- `SameSite=Strict`: Prevents CSRF attacks (cookie not sent on cross-origin requests)
- `Path=/admin`: Cookie only sent to admin routes

---

## Workers KV Configuration

### Namespace Setup

**Namespace name:** `MAGIC_LINK_TOKENS`

**Binding:** Configure in `wrangler.toml`:
```toml
[[kv_namespaces]]
binding = "MAGIC_LINK_TOKENS"
id = "your_kv_namespace_id"
```

### Key Naming Scheme

- **Magic link tokens:** `auth:token:{random_token}` ‚Üí value: `{email_address}`
- **Rate limiting:** `ratelimit:ip:{ip_address}` ‚Üí value: `{request_count}`

### TTL Strategy

- **Magic link tokens:** 900 seconds (15 minutes)
  - Set via `expirationTtl` parameter on KV put operation
  - Ensures tokens expire automatically
- **Rate limit counters:** 60 seconds (1 minute window)
  - Rolling window for rate limiting
  - Auto-cleanup via TTL

### Token Invalidation

**Single-use tokens:**
- Token deleted from KV immediately after successful authentication
- Prevents token reuse

**Expired tokens:**
- Auto-deleted by KV TTL mechanism
- No manual cleanup needed

### Eventual Consistency Handling

**KV Propagation:**
- Global propagation within 60 seconds
- Magic links are short-lived (15 min) and single-use

content.text:
Perfect! Let's get Phase 3 rolling. I've created the feature branch `feature/phase3-authentication` and mapped out the work.

## Phase 3: Authentication - What We're Building

**Magic link authentication system:**
1. User enters email at `/admin`
2. System generates secure token, stores in Workers KV
3. Email sent via Resend.com with magic link
4. User clicks link ‚Üí token verified ‚Üí JWT cookie set
5. JWT cookie authenticates all future admin requests

**Key components:**
- Magic link generation & storage (Workers KV)
- Email sending (Resend.com API)
- JWT-based session cookies
- Authentication middleware
- Login page UI
- Rate limiting (10 req/min per IP)

## Tasks Ahead (12 steps):

1. ‚è≥ Set up Workers KV namespace
2. ‚è≥ Update TypeScript types for env variables
3. ‚è≥ Magic link generation function
4. ‚è≥ Resend.com email integration
5. ‚è≥ JWT generation/verification
6. ‚è≥ Authentication middleware
7. ‚è≥ Login page UI
8. ‚è≥ API endpoint: send magic link
9. ‚è≥ API endpoint: verify token & set cookie
10. ‚è≥ Rate limiting
11. ‚è≥ Tests
12. ‚è≥ Documentation & secrets setup

**Should I start implementing, or do you want to review the plan first?**

content.thinking:
Great question! The user is asking about how we'll verify that the email attempting to log in is actually the admin email (Magnus's email). 

Looking at the specs:
- From blog-updates-security.md and blog-updates-mvp.md, I can see that there's an `ADMIN_EMAIL` secret mentioned
- The magic link should only be sent to this specific email address
- The spec says "Magic links only sent to this address" for the ADMIN_EMAIL configuration

So the pattern should be:
1. User submits email at /admin
2. We check if submitted email matches `env.ADMIN_EMAIL` (from Cloudflare Secrets)
3. If it matches, generate token and send magic link
4. If it doesn't match, return error (or maybe a fake success to avoid revealing valid emails)

The ADMIN_EMAIL is stored as a Cloudflare Secret, which is accessed via `env.ADMIN_EMAIL`.

Let me confirm this with the user and make sure they understand it will be a Cloudflare Secret.

content.text:
Excellent question! Here's the plan from the spec:

**Single Admin Email = Cloudflare Secret**

We'll store your email as a **Cloudflare Secret** called `ADMIN_EMAIL`. This gets set once via:

```bash
npx wrangler secret put ADMIN_EMAIL
# You'll be prompted to enter: magnus@youremail.com (or whatever you use)
```

**How the login flow checks it:**

1. User enters email at `/admin`
2. Worker compares: `submittedEmail === env.ADMIN_EMAIL`
3. **If match:** Generate token, send magic link ‚úÖ
4. **If no match:** Return error or fake success (to avoid email enumeration)

**Security considerations:**

Should we:
- **A) Return obvious error:** "Email not authorized" (simple, but reveals valid/invalid emails)
- **B) Return fake success:** "Check your email" (more secure, but confusing for you if you typo)
- **C) Return vague error:** "Invalid credentials" (balanced)

**My recommendation:** Option B for production security, but honestly for a single-user blog where only you know the admin URL exists, Option A is fine and more helpful if you typo your email.

What's your preference? And what email address should I use in example code/docs?

message.content:
Please go with Option B, that is best practice in my opininon. We may be small but we don't need to look small. :)

The email address: magnus.hultberg@gmail.com

content.text:
## üéâ Phase 3: Major Progress!

I've built the entire authentication infrastructure for your admin panel. Here's what's done:

### ‚úÖ What We've Built (9/11 tasks complete)

**Infrastructure Setup:**
- ‚úÖ Created Workers KV namespaces (AUTH_KV, RATE_LIMIT_KV)
- ‚úÖ Updated wrangler.toml with live namespace IDs
- ‚úÖ All TypeScript types updated for env variables

**Authentication Core (`src/auth.ts` - 270 lines):**
- ‚úÖ Magic link token generation (crypto.randomUUID)
- ‚úÖ Token storage in KV with 15-min TTL
- ‚úÖ Token verification with single-use enforcement
- ‚úÖ JWT generation & verification (HS256, 7-day expiry)
- ‚úÖ Authentication middleware (`requireAuth`)
- ‚úÖ Rate limiting (10 req/min per IP)
- ‚úÖ Email validation
- ‚úÖ Admin email check (magnus.hultberg@gmail.com)

**Email Integration (`src/email.ts`):**
- ‚úÖ Resend.com API integration
- ‚úÖ Beautifully formatted HTML email template
- ‚úÖ Security notices (15-min expiry, single-use)

**Admin Routes:**
- ‚úÖ `GET /admin` - Login page with email input
- ‚úÖ `POST /admin/api/send-magic-link` - Generates token, sends email
- ‚úÖ `GET /admin/api/verify-token` - Verifies token, sets JWT cookie
- ‚úÖ `GET /admin/dashboard` - Placeholder success page

**Security Features:**
- ‚úÖ **Option B implemented:** Always returns success (prevents email enumeration)
- ‚úÖ HttpOnly, Secure, SameSite=Strict cookies
- ‚úÖ CSP headers on all pages
- ‚úÖ Rate limiting
- ‚úÖ Single-use tokens with propagation protection

**Testing:**
- ‚úÖ All 44 existing tests still passing
- ‚úÖ TypeScript compilation clean
- ‚úÖ Mock ExecutionContext created for tests

### ‚è≥ What's Left (2 tasks):

1. **Write auth flow tests** - Test magic link generation, JWT verification, rate limiting
2. **Document secrets** - Update CLAUDE.md with required secrets setup

### üìä Code Added:

- `src/auth.ts` - 270 lines
- `src/email.ts` - 90 lines  
- `src/routes/adminLogin.ts` - 140 lines
- `src/routes/sendMagicLink.ts` - 85 lines
- `src/routes/verifyToken.ts` - 45 lines
- `src/routes/adminDashboard.ts` - 65 lines
- `tests/mocks/context.ts` - 15 lines
- Updated `src/index.ts`, `wrangler.toml`, all test files

**Total:** ~710 new lines of production code + routes + tests

---

## What You Can Do Next:

**Option A:** I finish the last 2 tasks (tests + docs) and we merge Phase 3
**Option B:** We commit what we have, and you can test the login flow manually first
**Option C:** Something else?

The authentication system is functionally complete and ready to test!

content.thinking:
The user wants me to finish the last 2 tasks (tests + docs) and is asking if they can test on localhost.

Good question - let me think about what's needed for localhost testing:

1. The code will run on localhost with `npm run dev`
2. BUT - they'll need the secrets configured for it to work:
   - ADMIN_EMAIL
   - JWT_SECRET
   - RESEND_API_KEY
   
3. For localhost, they can use a `.dev.vars` file (Wrangler's way of handling local secrets)

4. The KV namespaces are already configured with preview_id, so those should work

So yes, they CAN test on localhost, but they'll need to set up `.dev.vars` first.

Let me finish the 2 tasks and then give them instructions for localhost testing.

file.content:
- Use for critical infrastructure changes
  - Security-sensitive features
  - Major architectural decisions and initial review of new feature / project plans

### Deployment
Deployment to Cloudflare Workers happens via:
- Manual: `wrangler deploy`
- Automated: GitHub Actions (if configured)

## Environment & Secrets

Cloudflare Workers use secrets for sensitive configuration:

- Secrets are configured via `wrangler secret put <SECRET_NAME>`
- Never commit secrets to the repository
- Secrets are accessed via the `env` parameter in the Worker's fetch handler

Common secrets (check `src/types.ts` for the `Env` interface):
- API keys
- Authentication tokens
- Service credentials

## Testing

### Philosophy: Tests as Development Guardrails

**Critical Concept:** Tests in this project serve a dual purpose beyond traditional validation:

1. **Validation** - Verify code works correctly (traditional testing)
2. **Directional Context** - Guide AI agents on what to build and how to build it

input.new_string:
## Environment & Secrets

Cloudflare Workers use secrets for sensitive configuration:

- Secrets are configured via `wrangler secret put <SECRET_NAME>`
- Never commit secrets to the repository
- Secrets are accessed via the `env` parameter in the Worker's fetch handler

### Required Secrets (Phase 3+)

The following secrets must be configured for the admin authentication system to work:

#### ADMIN_EMAIL
**Purpose:** Email address authorized for admin access (single admin user)
**Value:** `magnus.hultberg@gmail.com`
**Setup:**
```bash
npx wrangler secret put ADMIN_EMAIL
# Enter: magnus.hultberg@gmail.com
```

#### JWT_SECRET
**Purpose:** Secret key for signing authentication JWTs (session tokens)
**Security:** Must be a strong random string (32+ characters recommended)
**Setup:**
```bash
npx wrangler secret put JWT_SECRET
# Enter: <generate a strong random string>
```

**Generate a strong JWT secret:**
```bash
# On macOS/Linux:
openssl rand -base64 32

# Or Node.js:
node -e "console.log(require('crypto').randomBytes(32).toString('base64'))"
```

#### RESEND_API_KEY
**Purpose:** API key for Resend.com email service (magic link emails)
**Obtain:** Sign up at https://resend.com and create an API key
**Setup:**
```bash
npx wrangler secret put RESEND_API_KEY
# Enter: re_xxxxxxxxx (your Resend API key)
```

**Resend.com Setup:**
1. Sign up at https://resend.com
2. Verify your domain (hultberg.org) or use Resend's test domain
3. Create an API key in the dashboard
4. Copy the key and paste when prompted

#### GITHUB_TOKEN (Phase 6+)
**Purpose:** GitHub Personal Access Token for committing updates via API
**Obtain:** Generate at https://github.com/settings/tokens (fine-grained token)
**Permissions:** Contents (Read and write) for `hultberg-org` repository
**Setup:**
```bash
npx wrangler secret put GITHUB_TOKEN
# Enter: github_pat_xxxxxxxxx (your GitHub token)
```

**Note:** This secret is only required in Phase 6 (Worker Backend API). Not needed for Phase 3-5.

### Verifying Secrets Configuration

Check which secrets are configured:
```bash
npx wrangler secret list
```

Delete a secret (if needed):
```bash
npx wrangler secret delete SECRET_NAME
```

### Local Development with Secrets

For local development (`npm run dev`), create a `.dev.vars` file (already in `.gitignore`):

```bash
# .dev.vars (DO NOT COMMIT)
ADMIN_EMAIL=magnus.hultberg@gmail.com
JWT_SECRET=local-dev-secret-key-not-for-production
RESEND_API_KEY=re_your_resend_api_key
REDACTED
```

Wrangler automatically loads `.dev.vars` during local development.

### KV Namespaces

In addition to secrets, the following KV namespaces are configured in `wrangler.toml`:

- **AUTH_KV** - Stores magic link tokens (15-minute TTL)
- **RATE_LIMIT_KV** - Stores rate limiting counters (1-minute TTL)

These are automatically available in the Worker via `env.AUTH_KV` and `env.RATE_LIMIT_KV`.

See `src/types.ts` for the complete `Env` interface with all available bindings.

```

**Resend.com Setup:**
1. Sign up at https://resend.com
2. Verify your domain (hultberg.org) or use Resend's test domain
3. Create an API key in the dashboard
4. Copy the key and paste when prompted

#### GITHUB_TOKEN (Phase 6+)
**Purpose:** GitHub Personal Access Token for committing updates via API
**Obtain:** Generate at https://github.com/settings/tokens (fine-grained token)
**Permissions:** Contents (Read and write) for `hultberg-org` repository
**Setup:**
```bash
npx wrangler secret put GITHUB_TOKEN
# Enter: github_pat_xxxxxxxxx (your GitHub token)
```

**Note:** This secret is only required in Phase 6 (Worker Backend API). Not needed for Phase 3-5.

### Verifying Secrets Configuration

Check which secrets are configured:
```bash
npx wrangler secret list
```

Delete a secret (if needed):
```bash
npx wrangler secret delete SECRET_NAME
```

### Local Development with Secrets

For local development (`npm run dev`), create a `.dev.vars` file (already in `.gitignore`):

```bash
# .dev.vars (DO NOT COMMIT)
ADMIN_EMAIL=magnus.hultberg@gmail.com
JWT_SECRET=local-dev-secret-key-not-for-production
RESEND_API_KEY=re_your_resend_api_key
REDACTED
```

Wrangler automatically loads `.dev.vars` during local development.

### KV Namespaces

In addition to secrets, the following KV namespaces are configured in `wrangler.toml`:

- **AUTH_KV** - Stores magic link tokens (15-minute TTL)
- **RATE_LIMIT_KV** - Stores rate limiting counters (1-minute TTL)

These are automatically available in the Worker via `env.AUTH_KV` and `env.RATE_LIMIT_KV`.

See `src/types.ts` for the complete `Env` interface with all available bindings.

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Rules of Engagement

Claude collaboration and ways of working instructions: @.claude/CLAUDE.md

When asked to remember anything, always add project memory in this CLAUDE.md (in the project root), not @.claude/CLAUDE.md, leave @.claude/CLAUDE.md as it is.

## Project Overview
This is a personal website for Magnus Hultberg (hultberg.org) built as a Cloudflare Worker. The architecture consists of:
- A TypeScript-based Cloudflare Worker (`src/index.ts`) that serves as the main entry point
- Static assets in the `public/` directory served through Cloudflare's asset handling
- Historical content including "now" pages with timestamped updates

We are currently implementing a blog feature in the site, see specification in [blog-style-updates-mvp.md](.REDACTED.md) 

## Getting Started

### Prerequisites
- Node.js (v18 or later)
- npm (comes with Node.js)
- Wrangler CLI (installed as dev dependency)
- Git
- GitHub CLI (`gh`) for PR operations

### Installation
```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone <repository-url>
cd hultberg-org

# Install dependencies
npm install

# Start local development server
npm run dev
```

The site will be available at `http://localhost:8787`

### Commands

#### Development
```bash
npm run dev        # Start local development server using Wrangler
```

#### Deployment
```bash
wrangler deploy    # Deploy to Cloudflare Workers (requires Wrangler authentication)
```

#### Testing
Note: The project currently has a placeholder test script that needs implementation.

```bash
npm test           # Currently exits with placeholder message
```

## Architecture

### Cloudflare Worker Structure
- **Entry Point**: `src/index.ts` - Main Worker export with fetch handler
- **Asset Handling**: Uses `@cloudflare/kv-asset-handler` for serving static files from `public/`
- **Configuration**: `wrangler.toml` defines Worker settings, compatibility date, and asset directory

### Static Content Organization
- **Public Directory**: Contains all static assets served by the Worker
- **Now Pages**: Historical snapshots in `public/now/` with timestamped filenames (format: `index_YYYYMMDD.CHANGED.html`)
- **Error Pages**: Custom 404 handling with `public/errors/not_found.html` and assets
- **SEO Files**: Standard web files like `sitemap_base.xml`, `foaf.rdf`, verification files

### Current Implementation Notes
Cloudflare Workers Assets serves static files from `public/` **before** the Worker's fetch handler runs (default `run_worker_first = false`). This means:
- Static assets (index.html, /now pages, images, etc.) are served directly by Cloudflare
- The Worker's fetch handler (`src/index.ts`) only executes for requests that don't match static files
- The Worker provides a custom 404 page with branding and helpful navigation for missing resources

The site is fully functional - there's no KV asset handler code needed in the Worker itself.

## TypeScript Configuration
- Target: ESNext modules for Cloudflare Workers runtime
- Strict mode enabled
- Cloudflare Workers types included
- Source maps enabled for debugging

## Project Structure

```
hultberg-org/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .claude/                  # Claude Code configuration
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ skills/               # Custom Claude Code skills
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ review-pr/        # Single-reviewer PR review skill
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ review-pr-team/   # Multi-reviewer PR review skill
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ public/                   # Static assets (served by Cloudflare)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ images/               # Site images
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ now/                  # Historical /now pages
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ errors/               # Error pages (404, etc.)
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ index.html            # Homepage
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/                      # TypeScript source code
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.ts              # Main Worker entry point
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ types.ts              # TypeScript type definitions
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ utils.ts              # Utility functions
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ SPECIFICATIONS/           # Feature specifications and requirements
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ *-plan.md             # Feature / project specification core documents
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ *-mvp.md              # Feature / project MVP specifications
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ *-security.md         # Security requirements
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ *-implementation.md   # Implementation plans
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CLAUDE.md                 # This file - project documentation
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json              # Dependencies and scripts
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tsconfig.json             # TypeScript configuration
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ wrangler.toml             # Cloudflare Workers configuration
```

### Key Files

- **`src/index.ts`** - Main Worker fetch handler, processes requests not matched by static assets
- **`src/types.ts`** - TypeScript interfaces for Worker environment and data structures
- **`src/utils.ts`** - Shared utility functions (slug generation, etc.)
- **`public/index.html`** - Homepage, served directly by Cloudflare
- **`wrangler.toml`** - Worker configuration including routes and asset handling
- **`SPECIFICATIONS/`** - Contains detailed feature specs, security requirements, and implementation plans

## Code Conventions

### File Comments
All TypeScript files should start with `// ABOUT:` comments explaining the file's purpose:

```typescript
// ABOUT: Brief description of file purpose
// ABOUT: Key functionality or responsibility
```

### Naming Conventions
- **Always provide context through naming** - Variable and parameter names should supply relevant context without needing additional documentation. Names like `AUTH_KV` and `RATE_LIMIT_KV` are preferable to generic names like `KV1` or `storage`.
- Use descriptive, meaningful names for variables and functions
- Follow TypeScript naming conventions (camelCase for variables/functions, PascalCase for types/interfaces)
- Avoid temporal references in names (no "new", "improved", "old", etc.)

### Comments
- Keep comments evergreen (describe what code does, not recent changes)
- Avoid over-commenting - code should be self-documenting where possible
- Add comments for complex logic or non-obvious decisions

## Development Workflow

### Creating Features
1. Create a feature branch from `main`: `git checkout -b feature/feature-name`
2. Check `SPECIFICATIONS/` for relevant feature specs
3. Implement following the specification and code conventions
4. Test locally with `npm run dev`
5. Create a PR when ready for review

### Pull Request Review
This project has two PR review skills available:

- **`/review-pr`** - Fast single full-stack developer review (~1-2 min)
  - Use for regular implementation PRs
  - Quick sanity checks
  - Standard feature work

- **`/review-pr-team`** - Comprehensive multi-perspective review (~3-5 min)
  - Use for critical infrastructure changes
  - Security-sensitive features
  - Major architectural decisions and initial review of new feature / project plans

### Deployment
Deployment to Cloudflare Workers happens via:
- Manual: `wrangler deploy`
- Automated: GitHub Actions (if configured)

## Environment & Secrets

Cloudflare Workers use secrets for sensitive configuration:

- Secrets are configured via `wrangler secret put <SECRET_NAME>`
- Never commit secrets to the repository
- Secrets are accessed via the `env` parameter in the Worker's fetch handler

Common secrets (check `src/types.ts` for the `Env` interface):
- API keys
- Authentication tokens
- Service credentials

## Testing

### Philosophy: Tests as Development Guardrails

**Critical Concept:** Tests in this project serve a dual purpose beyond traditional validation:

1. **Validation** - Verify code works correctly (traditional testing)
2. **Directional Context** - Guide AI agents on what to build and how to build it

Tests act as **executable specifications** that provide guardrails for agent-driven development. When an AI agent makes changes, tests should:
- Immediately signal if changes break existing functionality
- Provide clear context about what each component should do
- Make it obvious when a change is going in the wrong direction
- Serve as living documentation that agents can read and understand

**This approach is inspired by [OpenAI's Harness Engineering](https://openai.com/index/harness-engineering/)** and is essential for productive collaboration between human developers and AI agents.

**For complete testing strategy, philosophy, and implementation details:** [testing-strategy-plan.md](./SPECIFICATIONS/testing-strategy-plan.md)

### Test-Driven Development Workflow

**For new features:**
1. Write tests first that describe expected behavior
2. Implement minimum code to make tests pass
3. Refactor while keeping tests green
4. Verify 100% coverage of new code

**For bug fixes:**
1. Write failing test that reproduces the bug
2. Fix the bug to make test pass
3. Add edge case tests to prevent regression

### Running Tests

```bash
npm test                  # Run all tests once
npm run test:watch        # Watch mode for development
npm run test:coverage     # Generate coverage report
npm run test:ui           # Interactive UI for test exploration
npm run test:changed      # Run tests for changed files only
```

### Test Structure

```
tests/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ unit/          # Unit tests for individual functions
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ integration/   # Integration tests for routes and APIs
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ e2e/           # End-to-end workflow tests
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ mocks/         # Reusable mock implementations
```

**Test files mirror source structure:**
- `src/utils/slugGeneration.ts` ‚Üí `tests/unit/slugGeneration.test.ts`
- `src/routes/updatesList.ts` ‚Üí `tests/integration/updatesList.test.ts`

### Coverage Requirements

**Target:** 100% code coverage (every line should have a clear purpose)

**Enforced minimums:**
- 95% lines, functions, statements
- 90% branches

**Why 100%?** Untested code is unclear about its purpose and constraints. If we can't test it, maybe we don't need it. Agents need complete context about all code paths.

### Path Alias Configuration

Tests and source code use the `@/` path alias for clean imports:

```typescript
// Instead of: import { Env } from '../../src/types';
import { Env } from '@/types';
```

This improves readability and prevents brittle relative path imports.

### Clear Naming: Essential for Agent Context

**Critical principle:** Variable, parameter, function, and file names must communicate what they are about without needing additional documentation.

**Good naming examples:**
- `AUTH_KV` and `RATE_LIMIT_KV` (clear purpose) vs `KV1` and `KV2` (ambiguous)
- `generateSlugFromTitle()` vs `generate()`
- `isUserAuthenticated()` vs `check()`
- `tests/unit/slugGeneration.test.ts` vs `tests/test1.ts`

**Why this matters for agents:**
- Agents rely heavily on names to understand context and intent
- Descriptive names reduce the need for agents to read full implementations
- Clear names make tests self-documenting
- Good names prevent agents from making incorrect assumptions

**General naming conventions:**
- Use descriptive, meaningful names (not abbreviations unless standard)
- Follow TypeScript conventions (camelCase for variables/functions, PascalCase for types)
- Avoid temporal references (no "new", "improved", "old", etc.)
- Test files: `{module}.test.ts` format

### Test Principles

1. **Tests define expected behavior** - Living specifications
2. **Tests are self-contained** - Each test sets up and cleans up
3. **Tests fail fast with clear messages** - Explain what/where/why
4. **Tests are runnable in isolation** - No dependencies on other tests
5. **100% coverage goal** - Every line has clear purpose

### Mocking Strategy

**Reusable mocks in `tests/mocks/`:**
- `createMockKV()` - In-memory KVNamespace for testing
- `createMockEnv()` - Test environment configuration with sensible defaults

**What to mock:**
- External services (GitHub API, Resend API, Cloudflare KV)
- Static assets (file system reads)

**What NOT to mock:**
- Core logic (slug generation, markdown parsing, validation)
- These are the primary value of our code

### Pre-Commit Validation

Before committing, run:
```bash
npm test              # Verify all tests pass
npx tsc --noEmit      # Check TypeScript compilation
```

Future: Pre-commit hooks will automate this validation.

## Troubleshooting

### Local Development Issues

**Port already in use:**
```bash
# Kill existing Wrangler process
pkill -f wrangler
# Or specify a different port
wrangler dev --port 8788
```

**TypeScript errors:**
```bash
# Check TypeScript compilation
npx tsc --noEmit
```

**Dependency issues:**
```bash
# Clean install
rm -rf node_modules package-lock.json
npm install
```

### Deployment Issues

**Authentication errors:**
```bash
# Re-authenticate with Cloudflare
wrangler login
```

**Build failures:**
- Check TypeScript compilation with `npx tsc --noEmit`
- Ensure all dependencies are in `package.json`
- Verify `wrangler.toml` configuration is valid

## Technical Debt

This section tracks known technical debt and decisions to accept certain risks for MVP, with plans for future improvement.

### HTML Sanitization (XSS Prevention)

**Status:** Accepted risk for MVP (February 2026)

**Current Implementation:**
- Regex-based HTML sanitization in `src/routes/updatePage.ts`
- Removes dangerous tags (`script`, `iframe`, `object`, `embed`, etc.)
- Removes dangerous protocols (`javascript:`, `data:`, `vbscript:`, etc.)
- Removes inline event handlers and style attributes
- Located in `sanitizeHTML()` function with TODO comment

**Known Limitations:**
- Regex-based approach can potentially be bypassed with edge cases
- Does not implement proper allowlist-based tag/attribute filtering
- Industry best practice would be allowlist parser, not regex filtering

**Why This Is Acceptable for MVP:**

1. **Threat Model:** Single trusted admin (Magnus) - no untrusted user input
2. **Defense-in-Depth:**
   - Content Security Policy (CSP) headers block XSS execution even if sanitization fails
   - Server-side rendering only (no client-side markdown parsing)
   - HTML escaping for all metadata (title, author, excerpt)
   - Content version-controlled in GitHub (easy rollback)
3. **Risk Assessment:**
   - Main risk: Admin accidentally pastes malicious content into own blog
   - Secondary risk: GitHub account compromise (but then bigger problems exist)
   - CSP headers provide strong secondary defense

**Future Improvement Plan:**

Monitor these libraries for Cloudflare Workers compatibility:
- `isomorphic-dompurify` - Currently fails in Workers (as of Dec 2025)
- `sanitize-html` - Requires node::process, not available in Workers
- `worker-tools/html` - Templating library with built-in sanitization (requires rewrite)

**Decision Made:** February 2026 by Magnus (project owner)

**When to Revisit:**
- Before adding multi-user admin access
- Before accepting any form of public user input (comments, submissions)
- When Workers-compatible sanitization library becomes available
- If CSP headers are removed for any reason

**Testing:**
Comprehensive XSS test suite in `tests/integration/updatePage.test.ts` covering:
- Script tags and event handlers
- Case variation attacks
- Alternative protocols (vbscript:, data:)
- Dangerous tags (iframe, object, embed)
- Event handlers with unusual spacing
- Style attribute expressions
